posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Actually, sorcs are probably the worst choice for a high-mage Tenser exploit due to their lack of known spells even with the pally synergy going on.  It's easy for a wizard that recognizes dismal spell resistance situations (like SR monks, lotsa raks, constructs, demilichs... yada yada yada) to retool slots for maximum self-buffing and replace all the missile storms, wilting, bigby's and instakill necromancer spells to make a badass Tenser.  A sorc is stuck between a rock and a hard place.  Can't optimize offensive casting, dispelling and self-buffing all at the same time.

So it's not that nobody's considered it.  It's just that the concept only dominates under very specific conditions i.e. a one-trick pony.  Tenser's +3 sword will have trouble piercing serious DR. And the lack of gear merge of arcane polymorphs, in general, sux.  So while your Tenser waltzes onto the battleground, all those Greater Swordsman belts and Fire Resist rings on other players or NPCs will come back to haunt them.  The higher magic environments, with +10 and higher weapon enhancements will make Tenser's attack look foolish in comparison.  One Mord from a mid-high mage and the gig is up. I, myself, built a Dexer high-stealth hipser, epic dodger wiz26/rog13/sd1 focusing on the Tenser weapon that was uber until the enhancement levels began to neutralize the Tenser bonuses.  Tenser is more of an arcane get-out-of-jail-free card for spell resistance traps than a universal panacea.  

Monk class is essentially an exploit class with minimum level investment and no prereqs like with the prestige.  Free feats galore with just a 6-level commitment, the best attack progression in the game, best pre-epic saves, skill set only taking a backseat to rogues, bards and assassins... what's not to like?  The only downside is the alignment.  No bardic monks!

Fighter is the universal feat generator class with CoT a close 2nd there.  It makes it easy to achieve combat goals by virtue of all the proficiencies that would otherwise cost valuable feats to acquire.  Their armor proficiency is not limited like with barbs and rangers and they are not constricted by alignment. There is a lot to gain using that class in many, many builds.

Yes, DevCrit is nerfed on many of today's most popular servers. The popularity trend has become biased towards roleplay and away from H&S action.  Besides, DevCrit is also a one-trick-pony easily countered by PM10 or Shifter Risen Lord which is EXACTLY what you'll find when they leave it at default.  Damage adepts are generally the more reliable choice because their power is less effected by the sorts of creature encounters or gear props (like belts with Immunity: Critical Hits).

Yah.  The speed exploit is indeed crazy to witness.  We used to race DMs across the server with our toons using that spell/feat combination just for giggles on a slow night with many party no-shows.

Since you've expressed interest in a legacy build, I'll repost it like I just did with one of Mith's oldy moldies and try to grab as much of the discussion as possible.  I must be careful which ones to port over because building has changed a lot over the years and not all of those builds comply with v1.69.  (Don't want to confuse new players and aspiring toon builders.)  But I think Web's build is a great tutorial about how to get the most out of the wizard class so it should still be relevant today.  Be patient, though.  I am in and out on ECB for short periods at a time but I'll get to it.  Promise.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Shan't be poking holes, theflyingrodent (btw, do you have a preferred shorthand - Flying, Rodent, or simply The? Or something else?). I'm not that hot on build analysis, as others will attest. Indeed, I'm just coming up to my second anniversary of playing NwN, but I stumbled upon this site early on and have been annoying everyone with my "but why, Dad?" questions ever since. I'm afraid I'm not a magic fan, and am still trying to come to terms with the divine malarkey, let alone the arcane. I tend rather to the "Hulk bash, Hulk smash," heavy infantry school, but I'm learning.

Rather than just blathering on, however, I'll try addressing at least some of your introductory remarks.

1. Yes there are, but to be fair, I expect the Fighter element is mostly as a secondary or tertiary class - not wishing to demean the class at all, of course, but if you're going for melee and you're a tad feat starved, your first port of call would be... As to Monk, well, of course, because it's the singular best class in the universe. There may be one or two who'll try to gainsay that, but they're simply wrong. (let the games commence!)

2. It's an odd one this. When I joined here, the majority of STR builds were DevCritters, and I remember clearly the boyish delight of landing my first DevCrit. However, you're right that many places have indeed banned DevCrit now, but more - if we're constructing builds (and I'm using "we" to mostly mean "other people") that can be used universally (granted, with tweaks for environment and personal preference), It's often better to design one that can be used everywhere, then adapted to DevCrit if required, than design one that can only be used in a DevCrit environment, then deconstructed to use it everywhere else. Hope that makes sense.

3. Don't know, don't care. (Sorry, flippant. Had a scotch or two.)

4. Don't know, do care. Where did you come across that?

There, verbal diarrhoea finished for now.

EDIT: Bloody hell, I'm being ninja'd everywhere of late - Hip got me this time!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
theflyingrodent wrote:
What servers to people mainly populate these days? I'm from Australia so I expect silly ping but what the hey.


 
Yeah, that's a common problem, unfortunately.  Most of the servers seem to be posted along the U.S. leftcoast.  Max played WoG (one of the USWest PWs) from Brazil and never seemed to find much latency.  But it depends a lot on the server hardware, too.  Some of the well-established older servers haven't been upgrading their routers periodically so bandwidth gets hogged by the better hardware.

As I had indicated, the roleplay servers like Arelith, Amia, Thain, ArgentumRegio seem most popular.  Myself, I used to play WoG pretty regularly, but the patronage got pretty lean, I HATE to solo... so boring (a dyed-in-the-wool PnP party maniac) and the server goes down a lot for extended periods, usually about the time when I have opportunity to hack about.  I REALLY REALLY like Higher Ground because it is pseudo PnP with a lot of thought gone into maintaining the true spirit and fun of D&D though it is closer to 3.5e than NWN1's version.  Three Towns is a no-hak vanilla server that I could usually find some mates lurking around.

None of the aforementioned venues are high-magic.  All low-to-mid.  Some are pre-epic, some mid-epic.  HG goes up to legendary but I don't have the time to invest to amass that amount of XP so stick around level 25-35ish at best.  Then I get bored with a toon and start another from scratch.  It's usually a good idea to keep a few toons of different levels because you won't know what sort of party mix will be venturing when you log.  At least, that's been my own experience.

Many people like the eye candy of the custom servers more, though.  Through my own experience talking with players all around the world, it appears that many of the customizations can contribute to latency even when the traceroute is fairly close so there are some benefits with sticking to vanilla servers in that respect.  I mean, what's the advantage of spectacular vistas when your connection is getting dumped every 5 minutes trying to digest the leading edge graphics, right?

Dunno what server search you use, but the NWNList Scry seems to work fairly well.  The server status updates real-time which is handy.

The other recourse is to find other Aussie NWNers and set up LAN gaming sessions.  That's what we've done here locally and the FPS is always reliable (except during electrical storms, but hey... that's to be expected, right?).  Just throwing an alternative out there for consideration.  There are a lot of NWN modules that can be uploaded "as is" for LAN gaming and others that need some minor tweaking for multiplayer.

My best advice is to hunt down and try out all the vanilla ones first, one-by-one.  If not pleased, begin downloading the haks for the other servers and try those.  It'll be a bit tedious if a server doesn't work out after installing all their custom stuff and you'll feel like an interloper to a certain extent but eventually you'll find a few worth investing serious time into.  No doubt you've already gone through this same process in the past so, hopefully, all this will be old news.
